Infrastructure investments and services supported
column13: Using Malaysia as the regional hub for its Asia expansion, NEXTDC will also develop a new Regional Operations Centre for multidisciplinary staff to support growth across the Asian region. It will create the potential for continued investment in the area, with many Asian economies experiencing similar strong underlying economic tailwinds and rapid takeup of digital services.
column20: Regional Hub, Asia Expansion, Operations Centre

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column13: The Green Travel Plan (GTP) was established in 2021 for the S3 Sydney site in response to local government requirements on establishing safer and more sustainable travel to and from the facility for our staff, contractors, customers and visitors. The GTP addresses local traffic issues around the site and encourages active, safe, and sustainable travel methods, such as walking, cycling, riding a motorcycle, taking public transport, or sharing a car.
column20: Green Travel Plan, Sustainable Travel, Traffic Management

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column13: We actively pursue renewable electricity supply contracts as a component of the Company's electricity cost and risk management strategies (including investment in both on-site and off-site renewable generation).
column20: Renewable Electricity Supply, Contracts, Risk Management

column6: Significant indirect economic impacts
column13: An unpredictable transition to a low-carbon economy may cause abrupt and unplanned changes in market dynamics and pricing of these critical inputs and adversely affect financial performance. It may impact the procurement and pricing of electricity and fuel and could lead to service interruption.
column20: Low-carbon Economy, Market Dynamics, Financial Performance

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column13: NEXTDC's Partner Program supports an ecosystem of more than 750+ vendors, telcos, infrastructure, platforms, and cloud service providers. The business invests heavily in our local SMB network to support Australian start-ups and small businesses via partner agreements nationwide. With national pride, NEXTDC is creating jobs for our country.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column13: NEXTDC has an ecosystem of over 70 telecommunications carriers and several local and international infrastructure, platforms, applications, software, and Network-as-a-Service providers. Many of these providers are Australian companies that are powering the cloud computing revolution in Australia with their own diverse and ever-evolving service offerings.

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization
Energy intensity
column8: Continuous tuning of Mechanical, Electrical and Hydraulic areas for maximum efficiency
column13: NEXTDC's superior levels of energy efficiency are achieved through the rigorous efforts of NEXTDC's multi-award-winning Engineering and Operations teams, who continuously review the design and tuning of the Mechanical and Electrical Plant (MEP). The Operations specialists seek to optimise operational heat flow and power usage based on real-time power load data and seasonal ambient climatic conditions.
column20: Energy Efficiency, Operations Teams, Mechanical and Electrical Plant

column6: Energy intensity
column13: In addition, we are on our way to becoming Australia's first primary 'immersion-cooling ready' colocation provider. The system is a thermal management technique in which servers and storage devices are submerged in a thermally conductive but electrically insulating dielectric liquid or coolant. Our first Data Centre Immersion Cooling Suite was completed in 2022.
column20: Immersion Cooling, Data Centre, Thermal Management

column6: Energy intensity
column8: target PUE performance ranging between 1.15-1.29 at full load
column13: The energy efficiency goals for our second and third-generation facilities are to target PUE performance ranging between 1.15-1.29 at full load. It will be influenced by customer-required supply air temperatures, required UPS systems and local annual weather. In FY23, we engaged in various initiatives to minimise and continuously improve our PUE ratings alongside continuously tuning MEP for optimum efficiency.
column20: PUE Performance, MEP Tuning, Sustainability Initiatives

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: In supporting our sustainability goals and enhancing Customer Experience, in FY23, we installed Electric vehicle (EV) charging units at our S2, B2, M2, M3, and S3 facilities. It is a free service for our staff, customers, and visitors. By offering EV charging services, we consciously contribute to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and support the transition to cleaner transportation options.
column20: Electric Vehicle Charging, Greenhouse Gas Emissions, Cleaner Transportation

column6: Reduction of energy consumption
column13: As part of our energy management strategy, we control the portion of the data centres' power consumption not directly used for this purpose by tuning our facilities to optimise the efficiency of the support and backup infrastructure. This efficiency level is measured through the Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE) ratio, an internationally accepted standard metric used to rate the efficiency of data centres.

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column7: NEXTDC's Power Usage Efficiency ratio at the M1 and S1 data centres was vital to achieving a first-in-market National Australian Built Environment Rating System (NABERS) 5-star rating for data centre efficiency. In FY23, our P1 data centre achieved a NABERS 4.5 star rating. Efficient energy usage ultimately significantly impacts a data centre's sustainability, environmental footprint and profitability. All these goals are aligned and complementary and form the focus of our data centre designs and tuning cadence.

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: We plan to continually reduce our short- and long-term water needs and their environmental impact. Our proactive approach to responsible water management, as a minimum, complies with all water licensing requirements set by industry regulators.
column20: Water Management, Environmental Impact, Licensing Requirements

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: In the interest of repurposing this water, the team at S2 has been trialling a system that can capture and reuse this water. Our facilities are built-in locations that are safe during a 1 in 500 PMF event (possible maximum flood) and can have fuel supplies delivered during these events. The highly resilient evaporative water-cooling systems are expected to cool our data centres effectively during high temperatures.
column20: Water Repurposing, Flood Safety, Evaporative Cooling Systems

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column8: support the recapture and recycling of cooling tower water
column13: Rainwater tanks in our S3 facility capture rainwater used for toilets and garden watering. Before use, 11,000-litre rainwater tanks were installed with captured, filtered, and UV-treated water. The water is also used at the end-of-trip facilities, and the building has also been designed to support the recapture and recycling of cooling tower water.
